serge
Isn’t writing weird? It’s like you think things and then they’re on the page and then other people read them in their heads. Low key fan of alliteration.
Mar 13

Building the Batman We Deserve

With Ben Affleck leaving director duties behind on the new Batman movie, the franchise is in slow motion peril. But what if you could rebuild it and make it better, faster, stronger?

Serge: Man, watching Batman vs. Superman after the masterclass that is the Nolan trilogy felt like a disservice. I almost wanted to go back in time and prevent Nolan from making such perfect movies so they couldn’t be ruined by BvS. Actually, that’s an unwise use of one of my three wishes, I would prevent Zach Snyder from making any movies at all or murder the person who introduced him to slow motion shots. I think that would be a service to the world.

Anyways, now that Affleck is not directing again, we have to question if we’re going to get a good Batman movie again or are we destined for a Batman Forever/Batman & Robin scenario. None of which are too pleasant to think about. I do think that we can build a good Batman movie, what do you think Cam? I think we can at least use our collective knowledge of the Dark Knight and joint hatred of everything Zach Snyder has ever eaten an organically grown salad beside to put some ideas on paper to make the Batman movie we need right now, though not deserve because we let the Dark Knight’s fate stay with Zach for too long.

Cameron Climie: I only watched Batman vs. Superman in the last few months and, let me tell you, is it terrible. Not only was it awful, it didn’t have the good grace to be aware of how bad it was. I’m not nearly as high as you are on the Dark Knight trilogy — I particularly think that the third film goes off the rails in a couple of places, but I’m a huge fan of the Nolan films and just generally a huge fan of Batman media, whether it be the brooding, dark Batman of The Dark Knight or the even more brooding Batman of The Lego Movie. But with Affleck having been (thankfully) jettisoned from what was always an ill-advised relaunch of the Batman franchise, it’s time to sit back and consider: what would the ideal Batman be?

Serge: Okay. Before we take the dive I think it would be good to set some criteria. We need structure because without structure we just end up with Batman & Robin and then everyone who saw will need to go and have a lobotomy and I don’t want that. I want a good Batman film. I actually don’t want a Batman film at all but the relationship between Hollywood and money is such that money can be exchanged for luxurious and unnecessary goods and services such as Ferraris, plastic surgeries and Michael Bay movies. So we’re making a Batman film.

Origin Story is important in every superhero movie unless you’re Batman. Because we’ve had so many Batman movies I think it’s safe to say, we know what happens. But each movie manages to shoehorn this plot in so is it going to be explicitly shown? Is it a dream? Does he train himself? Does someone train him? Or my favourite… is it Flashpoint universe where Thomas Wayne is actually Batman?

For the sake of argument, let’s allow up to two villains. Why two? Because the golden standard of Batman movies is two (Joker and Two-Face) and the “holy shit this is a disaster” standard is three (Poison Ivy, Mr. Freeze and Bane). So two. That’s our scale.

Allies and Alfred are defining parts of Batman. So here we go. Alfred is there but we got to choose if he’s an obedient yes man or a military trained man in disguise like in some some series. Maybe he’s Batman’s father (running Wayne enterprises is a thankless job). Commissioner Gordon is unfuckwithable. He stays. So that gives us a variable catalogue of Batman allies to add a third into the mix. We’ll stop it right here because that time when Batman & Robin introduced Batgirl for no reason gave me depression. Now I’m depressed.

What kind of Gotham is it? Is it a realistic city that ebbs and flows or is it a sad cartoonist state of constant violence? What version of the city do you want to see.

I feel like… every Batman had some sort of a plot twist (aha, I’ve had rubber lips all along!). So we’re here. Just in case Batman finds out Alfred is his father.

Batman is not Batman without his gadgets or the batmobile. I remember the first time I saw Batman bust out on his bike in The Dark Knight and I gave a standing ovation. Do we get realism? Do we get laser nippers that can cut glass? Who knows.

Finally, pun fully intended, what is the final showdown? What is that scene where he defeats everyone. And not that bullshit where Bane gets taken out by one rocket after whipping the caped crusader like his momma used to.

Origin Story

Cameron Climie: I’m going to be straight with you: I freaking love Batman Begins. I think it’s the best Batman film and I don’t even think The Dark Knight gets close to it. And a lot of that starts with the sheer complexity and depth of its interpretation of Batman’s origin story. In most of the films and video-games that inhabit the Batman universe, we begin in media res with a fully-formed Batman, and are treated to his origin story via flashbacks or a handful of throwaway scenes. In Batman Begins, the film is the origin story; we get to see the formation of Bruce Wayne’s fascination with bats, his parents’ murder, his first draw to vigilantism, his training by the League of Shadows, and the creation and rise of Batman as a character and symbol. It also managed to do it in a way that felt fresh — every single repetition of the “Superman leaves Krypton” or “Peter Parker gets bit by spider” feels the same, and many of the repetitions of Batman’s origin story have felt similar. Batman Begins is the exception, and for that it gets my vote.

Serge: I don’t want an origins story, I honestly don’t, mostly because Batman Begins did it so well. I just don’t think anything can top this. Unless young Bruce Wayne yells “miss me with that fake shit,” jumps the robber and avenges his parents then and there I just don’t see a way it could surprise me anymore. I think we should just rely on our cultural knowledge of Bruce Wayne and not waste precious moments of screen time to explain to the audience that 2+2=4. In this case the twos are dead parents and 4 is the most kick ass Superhero in the history of superheroes.

Villain

Cameron: It just has to be Heath Ledger’s Joker. In the abstract, the character has become an all-time villain that ranks alongside Darth Vader and Hannibal Lector in the pantheon of evil. He’s complicated, psychotic, and the perfect ying to Batman’s yang. And it’s Ledger’s performance that is the most terrifying incarnation of the Joker. It does away with basically all of the camp that defined the character through the 1980s and 1990s and distills the character down to its core — a homicidal maniac who’s well-armed, methodical, and devious in his understanding of human nature.

For my second villain, I’m going in the complete opposite direction. Batman and Robin is easily one of the worst films ever made — it nearly killed the superhero movie, it was so bad. But what turns it from being just a horribly terrible movie into a gloriously terrible movie is the absurdity of Arnold Schwarzenegger’s Dr. Viktor Freeze, complete with ice-gun, cold-suit, and an avalanche of frost-related puns and jokes sufficient to bury the entire movie.

Serge: Man, why did you have to freeze me out like that? No. I got a tonne more. I’ve actually kept a journal of ice puns because of Batman & Robin. When I meet Clooney I want to personally present him with it. I think he’ll appreciate the gesture. But you know who I want to see done right in the Batman universe? The Riddler. Jim Carrey is a Canadian treasure, right up there with Keanu Reeves and Michael Myers, but his portrayal of Edward Nygma was almost as bad as Arnie as Freeze. At his best, the Riddler is Batman’s intellectual rival and his one pure goal seems to be just to prove that he’s the smartest man in the world. He’s literally doing it out of petty. On top of that there is a stint in the comics when he becomes a private detective. Think about it, Riddler is always outpaced by Batman at every turn in investigations and he turns to solve the greatest mystery of all, who is the Caped Crusader.

If we’re diving into figuring out who Batman is, the second villain has to be Hugo Strange who is criminally absent from most big screen adaptations. He is obsessive about finding out the Batman’s identity in a cute but like “dude back up or we’re going to have to get that restraining order” way. We see a lot of physical Dark Knight moments, but I want to see how he does against his intellectual rivals.

Ally

Cameron: Nightwing. A lot of the storylines of ally characters in both the Marvel and DC universes become too dependent on their main character, such that sidekicks are never able to truly step out of the shadows of their central characters. Dick Grayson’s Nightwing character somehow manages to do both: on the one hand, the character stands on its own as an interesting parallel to Batman’s conceptions of vigilantism, frequently employing a far more lethal brand of violence than his counterpart (never-mind that every single guy you fight in the Arkham games definitely has a concussion so severe that even Roger Goodell would think it’s a problem, but I digress). But his is also a character that struggles with the dark knight’s presence — in a storyline where Bruce Wayne is presumed dead, Grayson adopts the cowl himself and takes on the persona of Batman. To thread that needle so finely — to be trapped by Batman’s legacy and yet not — is a fascinating and thoroughly excellent play that doesn’t get nearly the credit it deserves.

Serge: God, I kind of want Barbara Gordon the low key hero of the Gordon family. However, given her tragic arc, it makes little to no sense to use her without the Clown Prince of Crime. So instead, I go with Damian Wayne. The son of Talia Al’Ghul and Bruce Wayne Damian is more like his psychotic grandfather than his calculated father. From the start he has no problem with killing and bloodshed which makes it even more difficult for Batman to turn him into the real Robin. He also has this incessant need to constantly impress his father. Damian Wayne has no time for all that honourable shit either.

Gotham

Cameron: As diverse as many of the interpretations of Batman’s most iconic villains and allies have been, there have been just as many different versions of the city that they inhabit. From Tim Burton’s neo-noir Gotham Batman and Batman Returns to the bizarre cartoony Gotham of Batman and Robin to the more realistic interpretations of the Nolan trilogy. I love the Chicago-esque feel of the first of the Nolan films, but didn’t enjoy its gradual transition to “Comic Book New York” in the later ones (even if Gotham is loosely based on New York City in the original comics), if only because it felt too similar to every other superhero that’s set in Fictional New York.

But my vote has to go to the Gotham of Batman: Arkham City. Besides just generally being an amazing videogame experience, Arkham City does the best job of threading the needle between the competing visions of Gotham — it has elements of the neo-noir, slightly cartoony style of the late 80s and early 90s, but also has the pulsating darkness of the Nolan films and the bleakness of Batman vs. Superman.

Serge: Oh man, I wanted to say Arkham City too because Arkham City is super dope as a game and as a concept. I also like that they’ve been able to contrive at least three different reasons for three different games about why the inhabitants should stay inside. Like, at what point do you move? Is the rent really that cheap and the jobs really that good at Gotham. Like, you must be making triple the regular wage at the local Starbucks to not at least consider going somewhere else. People drink coffee everyone dude, go to Metropolis, it’s right across the lake according to Zach Snyder.

They’ve modelled Gotham on so many cities before, like Chicago and Pittsburgh (for some damn reason), but I kind of want it to be the faux version of New York. In my mind wherever it is the Green Arrow and Flash are in the comics it’s California. Superman and his square chin clearly mark Metropolis as Boston. I think Gotham is New York. It has to be New York. So model it after that and call it Old York. Screw being subtle. I don’t know, just maybe rename the Burroughs.

Cam: Everything is rent-controlled. That’s my only explanation for Gotham being so popular whilst so violent.

Plot Twist

Cameron: That plot twist at the end of Arkham City where [REDACTED]. If you don’t know which one I’m referring to, just go play the game.

Serge: Edward Nygma working with Batman as a private detective reveals himself as the Riddler somewhere halfway through the movie. The case that we thought they were solving to track Hugo Strange is actually the Riddler’s elaborate plan to lure Batman deeper into the web of his own intrigue. Also, the Riddler doesn’t use any actual riddles. It’s a metaphor ya’ll.

Gadgets

Cameron: I really want to say “The Bat-Nipples from George Clooney’s Batsuit”, but I’m not going to. In actuality, I’m going with the Bat Credit Card from the same film. It’s literally the dumbest thing to appear in a superhero film ever, and it makes me crack up every time I see it. It represented everything that was preposterous about the Joel Schumacher film and is the most gaudy excess of the entire franchise. I love it.

Serge: I always picture Batman making 2$ purchases with it at the grocery store or something. Like he really wanted a Coconut Water but he didn’t have any cash so he just went in and when the clerk told him there’d be a 25 cent charge for a purchase under $5 he just laughs. Also, who charges Batman for stuff? He’s freakin’ Batman. That’s like charging your grandma for lemonade.

My favourite Batman was the animated series stuff where half of the equipment he had had no right of working and the other half was just physically impossible. Like, do you ever remember Spiderman swinging through a park and wondering “there aren’t any buildings he can use webs on here.” To escape Spiderman you just need to leave city limits or go to the suburbs. What is he going to do? But I digress. I think the best Batman moments are brought by iconic stuff that already kind of exists and wouldn’t be a problem to get for anyone with money. I want the grappling hooks and the ultralight goggles and everything in between. One thing I do ask for is, can we at least introduce the voice modulator? Just have a line about. Trust me, it will save you at least a decade worth of jokes.

Cameron: A voice modulator?! WHERE ARE THEY

Key Action Scene

Cameron: Continuing with my theme of “Batman Begins and then some other stuff”, it’s gotta be one of two scenes from the Nolan trilogy. The first is the amazing Tumbler scene in Batman Begins, with two dozen cop cars pursuing Batman’s half-car half-tank vehicle over the rooftops of Gotham as he attempts to get Rachel Dawes to the proto-Batcave. It’s a great scene that really demonstrated the full potential of Nolan’s universe, with a phenomenal backing score and even witty, non-punny dialogue (“He’s driving a black…tank.”) The other has to be any of the versions of Batman’s epic, brutal, literally back-breaking fight with Bane. I’m a big fan of the Nolan version if only because I always found the gimp-mask of the comics a little too cartoony for my tastes, but the scene (in film, TV, and comics) is so iconic precisely because it’s one of the first times that the dark knight meets his physical and psychological match. All of the elements of Batman’s persona that work on lesser villains — his strength, his deductive skills, his persistence — are liabilities to Bane’s military-precision intelligence and brutal strength.

Serge: Batman and Robin play hockey while defeating a gaggle of henchmen at the Natural History Museum. No? Fine. Given that all I’ve been building towards is a psychological breaking down of Bruce Wayne, I want the action scene to centre almost around him fighting himself, but because that’s not a thing, how about Batman against Damian Wayne? He takes on his younger son, driven by something orchestrated by the two villains and the two swashbuckle it out in the middle of an abandoned warehouse or something. He eventually snaps out of his whole “I birthed you so I will end” funk, but not before both heroes taking a severe beating from each other.

Serge: Allright, let’s tally it up. We don’t actually see the Wayne’s die, even though it heavily plays on the Batman’s conscience. This is further pushed when he clashes with Dr. Hugo Strange who works his magic to try and deduce who Batman. Wayne reaches out to Edward Nygma, P.I., and they try to track down strange before Nygma peeling away his facade and becoming the Riddler, deducing Batman’s identity. Teaming up with strange they decide to use Damian Wayne against his own father, in particular the strong emotional ties Batman has to his son mostly because his own parents died. Thanks to their efforts Batman enters a showdown with his own son in a 10 minute action epic of chases, fights and “I AM YOUR SON!” angsty screaming. In this movie, they actually explain the voice modulator and it all takes place in New York. I’m comfortable with that, I’d place it somewhere in the middle of Batman related quality. Maybe the upper third. What do you have?

Cameron: having reflected on my choices above,I’ve come to the realization that they don’t really fit together. Like, at all. I’ve got two films going at once — a gritty cross between the Nolan universe and Arkham City, and the camp awfulness of Batman and Robin’s ridiculous gadgets and ice puns. It’s a little unclear to me how those two fit with each other — does the campiness of the gadgets and secondary villain outclass the cold reality of Gotham and its psychopath of a primary villain? I don’t know. But I do know that the outcome probably still finishes above Batman and Robin, Batman Forever, and Batman vs Superman.

Serge: I’m all for setting low bars and Batman & Robin couldn’t set a lower bar if it was alone at a bar at 2:45am on Valentine’s Day.
